text: Big Idea 1: Represent, compare, and order whole numbers and join and separate sets.

children.text: Represent quantities with numbers up to 20, verbally, in writing, and with manipulatives.
Solve problems including those involving sets by counting, by using cardinal and ordinal numbers, by comparing, by ordering, and by creating sets up to 20.
Solve word problems involving simple joining and separating situations.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Represent quantities to 5 using sets of objects and number names.
Use one-to-one correspondence to count and compare sets of objects to 5.
Solve problems with up to 5 objects, involving simple joining (putting together) and separating (taking away) situations.
Represent quantities to 3 using sets of objects and number names.
Use one-to-one correspondence to count sets of objects to 3.
Solve problems with up to 3 objects involving simple joining (putting together) situations.
Respond to a prompt to indicate desire for more of a preferred, familiar action or object.
Respond to a prompt to indicate desire to stop an action or activity.
Respond to a counting cue to begin a familiar routine.
Demonstrate a favorable or positive response to a preferred stimulus.

text: Big Idea 2: Describe shapes and space.

children.text: Describe, sort and re-sort objects using a variety of attributes such as shape, size, and position.
Identify, name, describe and sort basic two-dimensional shapes such as squares, triangles, circles, rectangles, hexagons, and trapezoids.
Identify, name, describe, and sort three-dimensional shapes such as spheres, cubes and cylinders.
Interpret the physical world with geometric shapes and describe it with corresponding vocabulary.
Use basic shapes, spatial reasoning, and manipulatives to model objects in the environment and to construct more complex shapes.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Sort objects by single attributes, including shape and size.
Match and name twodimensional shapes, including circle and square.
Match examples of threedimensional objects, such as balls (spheres) and blocks (cubes).
Identify shapes, including circle and square, in the environment.
Identify spatial relationships, including in, out, up, down, top, bottom, on, and off.
Identify square objects or pictures when given the name.
Identify threedimensional objects, such as a block (cube) or ball (sphere).
Identify square shapes in the environment when given the name.
Identify spatial relationships, including on, off, up, and down.
Respond to a prompt to identify a familiar three-dimensional object in a familiar routine.
Respond to one directional prompt in a familiar routine.

text: Big Idea 3: Order objects by measurable attributes.

children.text: Compare and order objects indirectly or directly using measurable attributes such as length, height, and weight.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Compare overall size and length of objects and describe using terms such as big, small, long, and short.
Identify size of objects using terms such as big and little.
Respond to differences in familiar persons, actions, or objects within a familiar routine.

text: Big Idea 1: Develop understandings of addition and subtraction strategies for basic addition facts and related subtraction facts

children.text: Model addition and subtraction situations using the concepts of "part-whole," "adding to," "taking away from," "comparing," and "missing addend."
Identify, describe, and apply addition and subtraction as inverse operations.
Create and use increasingly sophisticated strategies, and use properties such as Commutative, Associative and Additive Identity, to add whole numbers.
Use counting strategies, number patterns, and models as a means for solving basic addition and subtraction fact problems.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Identify the meaning of addition as adding to and subtraction as taking away from.
Use counting and one-toone correspondence as strategies to solve addition facts with sums to 10 and related subtraction facts represented by numerals with sets of objects and pictures.
Demonstrate understanding of the meaning of joining (putting together) and separating (taking apart) sets of objects.
Use one-to-one correspondence as a strategy for solving simple number stories involving joining (putting together) and separating (taking apart) with sets of objects to 5.
Respond to the arrival of a familiar person or addition of a familiar object in a routine.
Respond to the departure of a familiar person or removal of a familiar object in a routine.

text: Big Idea 2:  Develop an understanding of whole number relationships, including grouping by tens and ones

children.text: Compare and order whole numbers at least to 100.
Represent two digit numbers in terms of tens and ones.
Order counting numbers, compare their relative magnitudes, and represent numbers on a number line.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Compare and order numbers 1 to 10.
Use one-to-one correspondence to count sets of objects or pictures to 10.
Represent numbers to 10 using sets of objects and pictures, number names, and numerals.
Use one-to-one correspondence to compare sets of objects to 5.
Use one-to-one correspondence to count sets of objects to 5 arranged in a row.
Represent quantities to 5 using sets of objects and number names.
Respond to a prompt to indicate desire for more of two or more preferred actions or objects in a familiar routine.
Respond to a prompt to indicate desire to stop two or more actions in a familiar routine.
Respond to a counting cue to begin two or more familiar routines.

text: Big Idea 3: Compose and decompose two-dimensional and three-dimensional geometric shapes

children.text: Use appropriate vocabulary to compare shapes according to attributes and properties such as number and lengths of sides, and number of vertices.
Compose and decompose plane and solid figures, including making predictions about them, to build an understanding of part-whole relationships and properties of shapes.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Sort and describe two-dimensional shapes by single attributes such as number of sides and straight or round sides.
Identify examples of three-dimensional objects, including sphere and cube.
Combine two shapes to make another shape and identify the whole-part relationship.
Describe spatial relationships, including over, under, front, back, and between.
Match common twodimensional objects by shape, including square and circle.
Name two-dimensional shapes, including circle and square.
Sort common two- and three-dimensional objects by size, including big and little.
Identify spatial relationships, including in, out, top, and bottom.
Respond to a prompt to identify a familiar object with a two-dimensional shape, such as circle or square in familiar routines.
Respond to a prompt to identify two or more familiar three-dimensional objects in familiar routines.
Demonstrate awareness of one discrete location (area) in the learning environment.
Respond to two directional prompts in familiar routines.

text: Big Idea 1:  Develop an understanding of base-ten numerations system and place-value concepts

children.text: Identify relationships between the digits and their place values through the thousands, including counting by tens and hundreds.
Identify and name numbers through thousands in terms of place value and apply this knowledge to expanded notation.
Compare and order multi-digit numbers through the thousands.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Apply the concept of grouping to create sets of tens and ones to 20 as a strategy to aid in counting.
Represent numbers to 20 using sets of objects and pictures, number names, and numerals.
Identify and use ordinal numbers to fifth.
Use one-to-one correspondence to count, compare, and order whole numbers 0 to 20.
Represent quantities to 5 or more using sets of objects, number names, and numerals.
Use one-to-one correspondence to count, compare, and order sets of objects to 5 or more.
Indicate desire to continue an action or activity by using an object in familiar routines.
Respond to familiar actions that represent the concept of none or stop in routines.
Respond to a counting cue to begin familiar routines in multiple settings.
Match one object to a designated space to show one-to-one correspondence.

text: Big Idea 2:  Develop quick recall of addition facts and related subtraction facts and fluency with multi-digit addition and subtraction

children.text: Recall basic addition and related subtraction facts.
Add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers through three digits with fluency by using a variety of strategies, including invented and standard algorithms and explanations of those procedures.
Estimate solutions to multi-digit addition and subtraction problems, through three digits.
Solve addition and subtraction problems that involve measurement and geometry.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Identify the meaning of the +, -, and = signs in addition and subtraction problems.
Use counting and one-to-one correspondence as strategies to solve problems involving addition facts with sums to 10 and related subtraction facts using numerals with sets of pictures.
Solve real-world problems involving addition facts with sums to 10 and related subtraction facts, including money, measurement, geometry, and other problem situations.
Identify the meaning of addition as adding to and subtraction as taking away from, using sets of objects.
Use counting and one-to- one correspondence as strategies to solve number stories involving addition facts with sums to 5 and related subtraction facts using sets of objects.
Solve real-world problems involving addition facts with sums to 5 and related subtraction facts using sets of objects.
Respond to the arrival of a familiar person or addition of a familiar object in the same activity in multiple settings.
Respond to the departure of a familiar person or removal of a familiar object in the same activity in multiple settings.
Continue in a routine with the addition of a familiar person, action, or object.
Continue in a familiar routine with the removal of a familiar person, action, or object.
Initiate a preferred action or activity by using an object.

text: Big Idea 3:  Develop an understanding of linear measurement and facility in measuring lengths

children.text: Estimate and use standard units, including inches and centimeters, to partition and measure lengths of objects.
Describe the inverse relationship between the size of a unit and number of units needed to measure a given object.
Apply the Transitive Property when comparing lengths of objects.
Estimate, select an appropriate tool, measure, and/or compute lengths to solve problems.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Use standard units of whole inches to measure the length of objects.
Compare and order objects of different lengths.
Select and use a ruler to measure and compare lengths to solve problems.
Measure the length of objects using nonstandard units of measure and count to 5 or more units.
Compare lengths of objects to solve real-world problems.
Respond to a prompt indicating size or length, such as big, little, long, or short in activities.

text: Big Idea 1:  Develop understandings of multiplication and division and strategies for basic multiplication facts and related division facts

children.text: Model multiplication and division including problems presented in context: repeated addition, multiplicative comparison, array, how many combinations, measurement, and partitioning.
Solve multiplication and division fact problems by using strategies that result from applying number properties.
Identify, describe, and apply division and multiplication as inverse operations.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Solve problems that involve combining (multiplying) equal sets with quantities to 18 using objects and pictures with numerals.
Solve addition facts with sums to 18 and related subtraction one-digit fact families using the formal algorithm with numerals and signs (+, -, =).
Use one-to-one correspondence, grouping, and counting as strategies to solve real-world problems involving addition facts with sums to 18 and related subtraction facts.
Use objects and pictures to represent the inverse relationship between addition and subtraction facts.
Solve addition facts with sums to 9 and related subtraction facts using numerals with objects and pictures.
Use one-to-one correspondence and counting as strategies to solve real-world problems with addition facts with sums to 9 and related subtraction facts.
Recognize when items have been added to or removed from groups of objects in daily activities.
Continue in a routine with the addition or removal of a familiar person, action, or object in two or more settings.

text: Big Idea 2:  Develop an understanding of fractions and fraction equivalence

children.text: Represent fractions, including fractions greater than one, using area, set and linear models.
Describe how the size of the fractional part is related to the number of equal sized pieces in the whole.
Compare and order fractions, including fractions greater than one, using models and strategies.
Use models to represent equivalent fractions, including fractions greater than one, and identify representations of equivalence.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Identify the relationship between half and whole.
Identify part and whole of objects.
Respond to prompt to indicate desire for less in a familiar routine.
Indicate desire for more in two or more routines or activities.
Indicate none or stop in two or more routines or activities.

text: Big Idea 3:  Describe and analyze properties of two-dimensional shapes

children.text: Describe, analyze, compare and classify two-dimensional shapes using sides and angles - including acute, obtuse, and right angles - and connect these ideas to the definition of shapes.
Compose, decompose, and transform polygons to make other polygons, including concave and convex polygons with three, four, five, six, eight, or ten sides.
Build, draw and analyze two-dimensional shapes from several orientations in order to examine and apply congruence and symmetry.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Identify attributes, including number of sides, curved or straight sides, and number of corners (angles), in two-dimensional shapes.
Combine (compose) and separate (decompose) two-dimensional shapes to make other shapes.
Identify two-dimensional shapes that are the same shape and size (congruent).
Sort two-dimensional shapes by single attributes, including numbers of sides and curved or straight sides.
Combine (compose) two shapes to make other shapes.
Match two-dimensional shapes that are the same shape and size (congruent).
Respond to a prompt to identify two or more familiar objects with two-dimensional shapes, such as circle and square in daily activities.
Respond to similarities and differences in features of two or more familiar objects in routines.
Given a model, imitate two or more directional responses in a daily activity.

text: Big Idea 1: Develop quick recall of multiplication facts and related division facts and fluency with whole number multiplication

children.text: Use and describe various models for multiplication in problem-solving situations, and demonstrate recall of basic multiplication and related division facts with ease.

Multiply multi-digit whole numbers through four digits fluently, demonstrating understanding of the standard algorithm, and checking for reasonableness of results, including solving real-world problems.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Solve problems involving combining (multiplying) or separating into (dividing) equal sets with quantities to 30 using objects and pictures with numerals.
Recall addition facts with sums to 18 and related subtraction facts.
Solve real-world addition and subtraction problems with two-digit numbers to 30 without regrouping, and check for accuracy.
Use properties such as the commutative and additive identity as strategies to solve addition problems.
Identify the meaning of the +, -, and = signs.
Solve addition facts with sums to 12 and related subtraction facts using numerals with sets of pictures and the +, -, and = signs.
Solve real-world problems involving addition facts with sums to 12 and related subtraction facts.
Recognize when items have been added to and removed from groups of objects in daily activities.
Continue in a familiar routine with the addition or removal of a familiar person, action, or object in three or more settings.

text: Big Idea 2: Develop an understanding of decimals, including the connection between fractions and decimals

children.text: Use decimals through the thousandths place to name numbers between whole numbers.
Describe decimals as an extension of the base-ten number system.
Relate equivalent fractions and decimals with and without models, including locations on a number line.
Compare and order decimals, and estimate fraction and decimal amounts in real-world problems.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Apply the concepts of counting, grouping, and place value with whole numbers to create sets of tens and ones to identify the value of whole numbers to 50.
Identify differences between halves, fourths, and a whole.
Express and represent fractions, including halves and fourths, as parts of a whole and parts of a set using objects, pictures, and number names.
Apply the concept of grouping to create sets of tens and ones to 18 as a strategy for counting objects.
Identify half as a part of a whole.
Communicate desire for more in one routine or familiar activity.
Communicate desire for none in a routine or familiar activity.
Indicate desire for less in routines.
Imitate counting two or more objects or actions in multiple activities.
Match one object to a like object or picture using one-to-one correspondence.

text: Big Idea 3: Develop an understanding of area and determine the area of two-dimensional shapes

children.text: Describe and determine area as the number of same-sized units that cover a region in the plane, recognizing that a unit square is the standard unit for measuring area.
Justify the formula for the area of the rectangle "area = base x height."
Select and use appropriate units, both customary and metric, strategies, and measuring tools to estimate and solve real-world area problems.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Identify examples of the distance around all sides (perimeter) and area of squares and rectangles in the environment.
Find the area of rectangular and square objects using square units.
Measure whole inches and feet using a ruler to solve real-world linear measurement problems.
Identify time to the quarter hour using a clock.
Identify the date and month using a calendar.
Measure weight using whole pounds and capacity using whole cups to solve real-world problems.
Identify examples of area in the environment.
Measure length of objects using whole inches.
Identify the capacity of containers as holds more or holds less.
Identify a clock as a tool to tell time.
Identify months using a calendar.
Identify similarities in the size of two or more familiar objects in daily activities.
Identify similarities in shape of familiar objects in daily activities.
Follow two or more directional instructions in routines or activities.
Indicate two or more locations of preferred objects or activities within the learning environment.

text: Big Idea 1: Develop an understanding of and fluency with division of whole numbers

children.text: Describe the process of finding quotients involving multi-digit dividends using models, place value, properties and the relationship of division to multiplication.
Estimate quotients or calculate them mentally depending on the context and numbers involved.
Interpret solutions to division situations including those with remainders depending on the context of the problem.
Divide multi-digit whole numbers fluently, including solving real-world problems, demonstrating understanding of the standard algorithm and checking the reasonableness of results.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Use a grouping strategy to separate (divide) quantities to 50 into equal sets using objects, coins, and pictures with numerals.
Solve problems that involve multiplying equal sets with quantities to 50 using objects and pictures with numerals.
Use counting and grouping to separate (divide) quantities to 18 into equal sets using objects and pictures with numerals.
Solve problems that involve combining (multiplying) equal sets with quantities to 18 using objects and pictures with numerals.
Recognize when items have been added to or removed from groups of objects in activities in two or more settings.
Continue in a familiar routine with the addition or removal of an unfamiliar person, action, or object in two or more settings.

text: Big Idea 2: Develop an understanding of and fluency with addition and subtraction of fractions and decimals

children.text: Represent addition and subtraction of decimals and fractions with like and unlike denominators using models, place value or properties.
Add and subtract fractions and decimals fluently and verify the reasonableness of results, including in problem situations.
Make reasonable estimates of fraction and decimal sums and differences, and use techniques for rounding.
Determine the prime factorization of numbers.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Express, represent, and use fractions including halves, fourths, and thirds, as parts of a whole and as parts of a set, using number names.
Compare fractional parts of objects of equal size, including halves, fourths, and thirds.
Use the associative property as a strategy to solve addition problems with three or more numbers.
Identify the relationship between half and whole.
Use the commutative property as a strategy to check the accuracy of solutions to addition problems.
Communicate desire for more in two or more routines or familiar activities.
Communicate desire for none in two or more routines or familiar activities.
Communicate desire for less in a routine or familiar activity.
Respond to a prompt to identify a specified part of a whole.

text: Big Idea 3: Describe three-dimensional shapes and analyze their properties, including volume and surface area

children.text: Analyze and compare the properties of two-dimensional figures and three-dimensional solids (polyhedra), including the number of edges, faces, vertices, and types of faces.
Describe, define and determine surface area and volume of prisms by using appropriate units and selecting strategies and tools.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Identify attributes, including curves, edges, angles, and faces, of three-dimensional objects in the environment.
Match two-dimensional shapes with three-dimensional solids, including circle with sphere, square with cube, and triangle with cone.
Use US customary units of measurement to measure length of sides of squares, rectangles, and triangles; and add them together to find the perimeter.
Find the area of rectangular and square shapes using a visual model, such as a grid.
Identify attributes, including number of sides, curved or straight sides, and number of corners (angles), in two-dimensional shapes.
Sort three-dimensional objects, including cube, cone, and sphere.
Identify examples of the distance around all sides (perimeter) of squares and rectangles.
Compare the size of two square areas in the environment using physical models.
Identify differences in features, such as shape and size of objects, in two or more familiar activities.
Follow two or more directional instructions in activities.
Locate familiar three-dimensional objects in daily activities.
Match an object, picture, or symbol with an identical object, picture, or symbol.

text: Big Idea 1: Develop an understanding of and fluency with multiplication and division of fractions and decimals

children.text: Explain and justify procedures for multiplying and dividing fractions and decimals.
Multiply and divide fractions and decimals efficiently.
Solve real-world problems involving multiplication and division of fractions and decimals.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Express and represent fractions, including halves, fourths, thirds, and eighths, using number names and numerals.
Solve real-world problems involving fractions, including halves, fourths, thirds, and eighths.
Identify multiplication as repeated addition of equal groups and multiply one-digit numbers using physical and visual models with numerals.
Identify division as repeated subtraction of equal groups and divide one-digit numbers using physical and visual models with numerals.
Identify fractions as part of a whole or part of a set.
Use fractions, including halves, to solve real-world problems.
Use skip counting by 5s and 10s to 50.
Solve problems that involve combining (multiplying) equal sets with quantities to 30 using objects and pictures with numerals.
Use counting and grouping to separate (divide) quantities to 30 into sets with the same number using objects or pictures.
Identify a specified part of a whole.
Communicate desire for familiar items to be added or removed in daily activities.
Communicate desire for more and none in two or more daily activities in different parts of the learning environment.
Communicate desire for less in two or more routines or familiar activities.

text: Big Idea 2: Connect ratio and rates to multiplication and division

children.text: Use reasoning about multiplication and division to solve ratio and rate problems.
Interpret and compare ratios and rates.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Describe the relationship (ratio) between two sets of data.
Identify two meanings of rate: a measure of speed, including miles per hour and words per minute; and a measure of cost, including price per gallon and cost per pound.
Identify the relationship between sets of paired numbers.
Identify the meaning of rate (how fast something moves or happens).
Identify differences in number of objects in daily activities.
Identify similarities in number of objects in daily activities.
Indicate awareness of changes in rates of movement (fast and slow).

text: Big Idea 3: Write, interpret, and use mathematical expressions and equations

children.text: Write and evaluate mathematical expressions that correspond to given situations.
Write, solve, and graph one- and two- step linear equations and inequalities.
Works backward with two-step function rules to undo expressions.
Solve problems given a formula.
Apply the Commutative, Associative, and Distributive Properties to show that two expressions are equivalent.
Construct and analyze tables, graphs and equations to describe linear functions and other simple relations using both common language and algebraic notation.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Write and solve number sentences (equations) that correspond to real-world problem situations involving addition and subtraction with two-digit numbers.
Use models and diagrams to solve problems with inequalities, including the > and < signs.
Identify rules that use addition and subtraction for functions represented in number pairs.
Use the commutative and associative properties of addition to show that two number sentences (equations) are equal.
Solve addition and subtraction number sentences (equations) using information from physical models, diagrams, and tables.
Use visual models, such as tables, to show the relationship between addition and subtraction problems.
Write and solve number sentences (equations) that correspond to real-world problem situations involving addition and subtraction with one-digit numbers.
Use physical models and diagrams to solve problems with inequalities, including the terms more than and less than.
Use the commutative property of addition to show that two number sentences represented by physical and visual models are equal.
Use visual models, such as two-column tables, to represent the relationship of addition and subtraction basic facts.
Use information from physical models, diagrams, tables, and pictographs to solve number sentences (equations) involving addition and subtraction with one-digit numbers.
Follow a prompt to identify a missing item from a familiar set.
Indicate the next step in a sequence for two or more activities.
Match a repeating pattern with two elements in two or more routines or activities.
Indicate 1 and 1 more by imitating a model in more than one activity.

text: Big Idea 1: Develop an understanding of an apply proportionality, including similarity

children.text: Distinguish between situations that are proportional or not proportional and use proportions to solve problems.
Solve percent problems, including problems involving discounts, simple interest, taxes, tips and percents of increase or decrease.
Solve problems involving similar figures.
Graph proportional relationships and identify the unit rate as the slope of the related linear function.
Distinguish direct variation from other relationships, including inverse variation.
Apply proportionality to measurement in multiple contexts, including scale drawings and constant speed.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Use ratio to solve real-world problems using physical models, graphic representations, and charts.
Identify that a higher percent represents a larger quantity or amount in real-world problems.
Describe how models compare in size to real-life objects.
Use simple ratios to solve real-world problems using objects.
Identify that percent discounts reduce the price of goods in real-world situations.
Compare the size of models to real-life objects using terms such as same, larger, and smaller.
Select large or small version of the same object in daily activities.
Match two different objects, pictures, or symbols presented at the same time to identical objects, pictures, or symbols using the concept of one-to-one correspondence.

text: Big Idea 2: Develop an understanding of and use formulas to determine surface areas and volumes of three-dimensional shapes

children.text: Justify and apply formulas for surface area and volume of pyramids, prisms, cylinders, and cones.
Use formulas to find surface areas and volume of three-dimensional composite shapes.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Identify the six faces of a three-dimensional rectangular prism or cube.
Use stated formulas to solve for perimeter and area of rectangles.
Solve real-world problems involving capacity using standard units of measure including cups, pints, quarts, and gallon.
Find the area of rectangular and square objects using square units.
Add lengths of sides of rectangles to determine the distance around (perimeter).
Match common two-dimensional shapes with three-dimensional solids, including circle with sphere, square with cube, and triangle with cone.
Use US customary units to measure cups and gallons.
Identify objects or pictures that are the same size in daily activities.
Place familiar objects in two or more designated locations and areas in routines.

text: Big Idea 3: Develop an understanding of operations on all rational numbers and solving linear equations

children.text: Use and justify the rules for adding, subtracting, multiplying, dividing, and finding the absolute value of integers.

Add, subtract, multiply, and divide integers, fractions, and terminating decimals, and perform exponential operations with rational bases and whole number exponents including solving problems in everyday contexts.
Formulate and use different strategies to solve one-step and two-step linear equations, including equations with rational coefficients.
Use the properties of equality to represent an equation in a different way and to show that two equations are equivalent in a given context.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Solve number sentences (equations) involving addition and subtraction of numbers to 500.
Translate real-world problem situations into number sentences (equations) involving addition and subtraction of two-digit numbers using a problem solving strategy.
Use physical and visual models to represent the inverse relationship between multiplication and division.
Use the property of equality as a strategy to solve real-world problems.
Add and subtract one-digit and two-digit number sentences (equations).
Write and solve number sentences (equations) that correspond to real-world problem situations involving addition and subtraction with one-digit and two-digit numbers.
Solve problems that involve combining (multiplying) equal sets with quantities to 50 using objects and pictures with numerals.
Use counting and grouping to separate (divide) quantities to 50 into sets with the same number using objects or pictures.
Use skip counting by 5s and 10s to 60.
Use physical models to solve simple problems to demonstrate the concept of equality.
Imitate a model of adding 1 more to quantities to 3 in a routine or activity.
Imitate a model of taking 1 away from quantities to 3 in a routine or activity.
Identify a missing item from two or more familiar sets given a model.
Follow a repeating pattern with three or more elements in a familiar routine or activity.
Indicate next steps in a sequence for a familiar routine or activity.

text: Big Idea 1: Analyze and represent linear functions and solve linear equations and systems of linear equations

children.text: Create and interpret tables, graphs, and models to represent, analyze, and solve problems related to linear equations, including analysis of domain, range and the difference between discrete and continuous data.
Interpret the slope and the x- and y-intercepts when graphing a linear equation for a real-world problem.
Use tables, graphs, and models to represent, analyze, and solve real-world problems related to systems of linear equations.
Identify the solution to a system of linear equations using graphs.
Translate among verbal, tabular, graphical and algebraic representations of linear functions.
Compare the graphs of linear and non-linear functions for real-world situations.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Use information from physical models, diagrams, tables, and graphs to solve addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division number sentences (equations) based on real-world problems.
Identify the relationship between two sets of related data such as ordered number pairs in a table.
Translate problem situations into number sentences (equations) involving addition and subtraction of two-digit numbers and multiplication and division facts using a problem solving strategy.
Use information from physical models, diagrams, tables, and pictographs to solve number sentences (equations) involving addition and subtraction with one-digit and two-digit numbers.
Describe the relationship (1 more or 1 less) between two sets of related numbers.
Translate real-world situations into number sentences (equations) involving addition and subtraction using information from physical and visual models, tables, and pictographs.
Use counting and grouping to join (multiply) and separate (divide) quantities to 50 using sets with the same number of objects or pictures to solve real-world problems.
Identify missing items from familiar sets.
Follow a repeating pattern with three or more elements in a familiar routine or activity in two or more settings.

text: Big Idea 2: Analyze two- and three-dimensional figures by using distance and angle

children.text: Use similar triangles to solve problems that include height and distances.
Classify and determine the measure of angles, including angles created when parallel lines are cut by transversals.
Demonstrate that the sum of the angles in a triangle is 180-degrees and apply this fact to find unknown measure of angles, and the sum of angles in polygons.
Validate and apply Pythagorean Theorem to find distances in real world situations or between points in the coordinate plane.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Identify triangles that are the same shape but different size (similar) using physical and visual models.
Form intersecting lines and identify the angles as acute, obtuse, or right angles using a model of a right angle.
Identify examples of parallel lines in the environment.
Identify angles within triangles as acute, obtuse, or right angles using a right angle as a model.
Measure the sides of a right triangle to determine the perimeter.
Locate the right angle and the side opposite the right angle (hypotenuse) in a right triangle.
Match triangles that are the same shape but different size (similar) using physical models.
Identify angles formed by lines that cross (intersecting lines).
Locate the right angle within a triangle.
Measure the length of each side of a triangle.
Demonstrate understanding of three or more directional concepts in daily activities in more than one setting.
Place familiar objects in three or more designated locations in routines and activities.
Match familiar objects or pictures based on a given feature, such as color, size, or shape, to complete tasks in activities.
Select large or small version of two or more objects in daily activities.

text: Big Idea 3: Analyze and summarize data sets

children.text: Select, organize and construct appropriate data displays, including box and whisker plots, scatter plots, and lines of best fit to convey information and make conjectures about possible relationships.
Determine and describe how changes in data values impact measures of central tendency.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Organize data into categories, identify the labels, and display in bar and simple line graphs.
Determine the largest and smallest numbers in a set of data, the number that occurs most often (mode), and the number in the middle (median) of a set of data with up to 9 numbers.
Organize data in pictographs and match the labels for categories.
Identify the number that occurs most frequently (mode) in a set of data with up to 5 numbers.
Count the objects, pictures, or symbols used in a pictograph or chart and identify a total to 3 or more.

text: Supporting Ideas

children.text: Algebra
Identify and duplicate simple number and non-numeric repeating and growing patterns.
Extend repeating and growing patterns, fill in missing terms, and justify reasoning.
Extend number patterns to build a foundation for understanding multiples and factors - for example, skip counting by 2's, 5's, 10's.
Classify numbers as odd or even and explain why.
Generalize numeric and non-numeric patterns using words and tables.
Describe and apply equality to solve problems, such as in balancing situations.
Recognize and state rules for functions that use addition and subtraction.
Create, analyze, and represent patterns and relationships using words, variables, tables and graphs.
Generate algebraic rules and use all four operations to describe patterns, including nonnumeric growing or repeating patterns.
Describe mathematics relationships using expressions, equations, and visual representations.
Recognize and write algebraic expressions for functions with two operations.
Use the properties of equality to solve numerical and real world situations.
Construct and describe a graph showing continuous data, such as a graph of a quantity that changes over time.
Solve literal equations for a specified variable.
Solve and graph one- and two-step inequalities in one variable.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Match two-element repeating patterns of sounds, physical movements, and objects.
Match identical sounds, physical movements, and objects.
Demonstrate distinctive responses to preferred vs. non-preferred stimuli in a familiar routine.
Match a two-element repeating visual pattern.
Match objects by single attributes such as color, shape, or size.
Indicate anticipation of next step in a familiar routine or activity.
Identify two-element repeating visual patterns and extend with one repetition.
Fill in missing items in twoelement repeating visual patterns.
Identify equal and unequal sets of objects and pictures to 20.
Match two-element repeating patterns of sounds, physical movements, and objects.
Use one-to-one correspondence to identify sets of objects with the same number to 5.
Follow a two-element repeating pattern in a familiar routine or activity.
Indicate anticipation of next step(s) in the same routine or activity in multiple settings.
Recognize similarities and differences in features of familiar objects and actions in routines.
Complete growing visual and number patterns.
Identify the rule, including 1 more, 2 more and 3 more, represented in number pairs.
Match a two-element repeating visual pattern using objects and pictures.
Use the rule 1 more to identify the next number with numbers 1 to 10.
Follow a two-element repeating pattern with two elements in two or more familiar routines or activities.
Identify items that belong together to complete a set in one routine or activity.
Communicate anticipation of next step(s) in a sequence of familiar activities.
Identify and extend growing visual and number patterns.
Describe equal and unequal sets using terms including greater than, less than, and equal to.
Identify the rule, including 1 less, 2 less, and 3 less, represented in number pairs.
Identify and copy twoelement repeating visual patterns using objects and pictures.
Determine if the number in two sets of objects to 10 are same or different (equal or unequal).
Use the rule 1 more to identify the next number with numbers 1 to 20.
Identify items that belong together to complete a set in routines or activities.
Follow a two-element repeating pattern in two or more routines, activities, or settings.
Indicate the next step in a familiar sequence of an activity.
Indicate the end of a familiar sequence of an activity.
Use the concept of equality as a strategy to solve problems.
Describe the meaning of information in a pictograph or bar graph that shows change over time.
Identify and compare the relationship between two same or different (equal or unequal) sets to 18 using physical and visual models.
Identify information displayed on an object graph or pictograph.
Identify items that belong together to complete two or more sets in routines or activities.
Identify differences in features of objects and actions in familiar activities.
Match a repeating pattern with two elements in a familiar routine or activity.
Indicate the next step in a sequence for an activity.
Indicate the end of two regularly occurring activities.
Identify the meaning of the variables in stated formulas (literal equations) to solve problems involving area and perimeter.
Translate real-world problem situations into number sentences (equations and inequalities) involving addition, subtraction, and multiplication using visual models, tables, and graphs.
Demonstrate how to determine the total length of all the sides (perimeter) of figures such as rectangles to solve problems.
Translate real-world problem situations into number sentences (equations) involving addition and subtraction of one-digit and twodigit numbers using physical and visual models and tables.
Identify a given quantity to 3 or more and add 1 more in an activity to solve problems.
Identify a given quantity to 3 or more and take away 1 in an activity to solve problems.
Geometry and Measurement
Demonstrate an understanding of the concept of time using identifiers such as morning, afternoon, day, week, month, year, before/after, and shorter/longer.
Measure by using iterations of a unit and count the unit measures by grouping units.
Compare and order objects according to descriptors of length, weight and capacity.
Use geometric models to demonstrate the relationships between wholes and their parts as a foundation to fractions.
Identify time to the nearest hour and half hour.
Identify, combine, and compare values of money in cents up to $1 and in dollars up to $100, working with a single unit of currency.

Measure weight/mass and capacity/volume of objects. Include the use of the appropriate unit of measure and their abbreviations including cups, pints, quarts, gallons, ounces (oz), pounds (lbs), grams (g), kilograms (kg), milliliters (mL) and liters (L).
Select appropriate units, strategies and tools to solve problems involving perimeter.
Measure objects using fractional parts of linear units such as ½, ¼, and <sup>1</sup>/<sub>10</sub>
Tell time to the nearest minute and to the nearest quarter hour, and determine the amount of time elapsed.
Classify angles of two-dimensional shapes using benchmark angles (i.e. 45°, 90°, 180°, and 360°).
Identify and describe the results of translations, reflections, and rotations of 45, 90, 180, 270, and 360 degrees, including figures with line and rotational symmetry.
Identify and build a three-dimensional object from a two-dimensional representation of that object and vice versa.
Identify and plot ordered pairs on the first quadrant of the coordinate plane.
Compare, contrast, and convert units of measure within the same dimension (length, mass, or time) to solve problems.
Solve problems requiring attention to approximation, selection of appropriate measuring tools, and precision of measurement.
Derive and apply formulas for areas of parallelograms, triangles, and trapezoids from the area of a rectangle.
Understand the concept of p, know common estimates of p (3.14; 22/7) and use these values to estimate and calculate the circumference and the area of circles.
Find the perimeters and areas of composite two-dimensional figures, including non-rectangular figures (such as semicircles) using various strategies.
Determine a missing dimension of a plane figure or prism, given its area or volume and some of the dimensions, or determine the area or volume given the dimensions.
Determine how changes in dimensions affect the perimeter, area, and volume of common geometric figures and apply these relationships to solve problems.
Predict the results of transformations and draw transformed figures, with and without the coordinate plane.
Identify and plot ordered pairs in all four quadrants of the coordinate plane.
Compare, contrast, and convert units of measure between different measurement systems (US customary or metric (SI)), dimensions, and derived units to solve problems.

Compare, contrast, and convert units of measure between different measurement systems (US customary or metric (SI)) and dimensions including temperature, area, volume, and derived units to solve problems.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Identify concepts of time, including day, night, morning, and afternoon, by relating activities to a time period.
Identify concepts of time, including day and night, by relating daily events to a time period.
Respond to the environmental cue for a preferred activity within a regularly scheduled routine.
Measure length of objects using nonstandard units of measure and count the units.
Compare objects by concepts of length, using terms like longer, shorter, and same; and capacity, using terms like full and empty.
Identify concepts of time, including before, after, and next, by relating daily events to a time period.
Measure length of objects using nonstandard units of measure.
Compare objects by length using terms like long and short.
Identify the concepts of time, including morning and afternoon, by relating daily events to a time period.
Respond to differences in familiar persons, actions, or objects in two or more familiar routines.
Respond to the environmental cue for preferred activities within regularly scheduled routines.
Match parts with the whole using geometric shapes.
Identify concepts of time, including yesterday, today, tomorrow, first, and next, by relating activities with the time period.
Identify the days of the week in relation to the calendar.
Identify analog and digital clocks as tools for telling time.
Identify the purpose of coins and bills.
Compare objects by weight, using terms including heavy and light; and capacity, using terms including holds more and holds less.
Identify part and whole of geometric shapes.
Match common three-dimensional objects by shape, including sphere and cube.
Identify the concepts of time, including before, after, and next, by relating activities with the time period.
Identify coins as money.
Compare weight of objects using the concepts of heavy and light.
Identify and describe spatial relationships, including over, under, front, back, and between.
Respond to differences in features such as size and shape of familiar objects in routines.
Respond to the environmental cue for a non-preferred activity within a regularly scheduled routine.
Respond to icons or symbols representing activities in an adaptive schedule.
Given a model, imitate one or more directional responses in a daily activity.
Use a ruler to solve problems involving the length of sides of squares and rectangles.
Measure length to the whole inch or foot, weight to the pound, and capacity to the cup to solve problems.
Identify time to hour and half hour.
Identify the months of the year in relation to calendars.
Use nonstandard measurement units to solve problems for length of sides of squares.
Use nonstandard measurement units to solve problems with weight, including concepts of heavy and light.
Identify concepts of time, including yesterday, today, and tomorrow, by relating activities to the time period.
Identify the days of the week using a calendar.
Indicate area (location) of preferred object or activity within a learning environment.
Associate the environmental cue related to time of an activity with an object, picture, or symbol used in a daily schedule.
Identify an object, picture, or symbol associated with an activity in the daily schedule.
Locate angles in twodimensional shapes including triangles and rectangles.

Identify examples of two-dimensional figures that are the same shape and size (congruency) and figures that are visually the same on both sides of a central dividing line (symmetry) in the environment.
Sort three-dimensional objects, such as cubes, cylinders, cones, rectangular prisms, and spheres.
Locate angles within a triangle.
Identify two-dimensional figures that are visually the same on both sides of a central dividing line (symmetry).
Match three-dimensional objects with models, such as a cube, cylinder, cone, and sphere.
Identify differences in familiar objects with two-dimensional shapes, such as circle, square, or triangle.
Identify two or more familiar three-dimensional objects in daily activities.
Identify objects, pictures, or symbols associated with two or more activities in the daily schedule.
Indicate the relative position, before or after, of whole numbers on a 0-50 number line.
Solve real-world problems involving length, weight, and capacity of objects using tools with standard units.
Identify time to the minute.
Indicate the relative position, before or after, of whole numbers on a 1-10 number line.
Solve real-world problems by comparing the measurement including length, weight, and capacity of objects.
Identify time to the hour and half-hour.
Identify differences in large and small objects in daily activities.
Indicate the next regularly occurring activity in the daily schedule sequence.
Compare the distance around the outside of circles (circumference) using physical or visual models.
Measure the distance around all sides (perimeter) of polygons, such as squares, triangles, rectangles, and hexagons.
Compare areas of circles using visual models.
Measure capacity using cups, pints, quarts, and gallons.
Identify the distance around the outside of circles (circumference).
Measure the lengths of sides of rectangles and triangles.
Compare the areas of rectangular and square shapes using physical models.
Compare areas of circles using physical models.
Measure capacity using cups.
Place familiar objects in designated locations in routines.
Follow three or more directional instructions in daily activities.
Identify differences in objects with two-dimensional shapes, such as circle, square, or triangle.
Indicate the next regularly occurring activity in the daily schedule.
Identify the effects of changes in the lengths of sides of rectangles on the perimeter and area using physical and visual models.
Solve problems involving rate, including as a measure of speed and a measure of cost.
Identify examples of slides (translations), turns (rotations), and flips (reflections) of geometric figures using pictures and objects.
Compare angles to a model of a right angle to identify the angles as acute, obtuse, or right angles.
Use tools such as charts and technology to convert measures of capacity including cups, pints, quarts, and gallons.
Recognize that changes in the lengths of sides of rectangles will make the figure or object smaller or larger.
Identify examples of rate in real-world situations.
Match identical (congruent) geometric figures in different positions, including flips (reflections) and turns (rotations).
Identify angles in the environment.
Identify time to the quarter hour using a clock.
Identify the number of cups in a pint to convert measures of capacity.
Match a three-dimensional object to a like object with two options.
Recognize fast and slow rates of movement in different settings.
Indicate the next two regularly occurring activities in the daily schedule.
Follow three or more directional instructions in daily activities.
Use tools such as charts and technology to convert measures within the same system, including money, length, time and capacity.
Identify standard units of measurement for length, weight, and capacity.
Identify time to the minute using a clock.
Match familiar two-dimensional figures based on a given feature, such as size and shape to complete tasks in activities.
Use a daily schedule to transition from one activity to the next in the school setting.
Number and Operations
Use mathematical reasoning and beginning understanding of tens and ones, including the use of invented strategies, to solve two-digit addition and subtraction problems
Solve routine and non-routine problems by acting them out, using manipulatives, and drawing diagrams
Solve problems that involve repeated addition.
Represent, compute, estimate and solve problems using numbers through hundred thousands.
Solve non-routine problems by making a table, chart, or list and searching for patterns.
Use and represent numbers through millions in various contexts, including estimation of relative sizes of amounts or distances.

Use models to represent division as:
  • the inverse of multiplication
  • as partitioning
  • as successive subtraction
Generate equivalent fractions and simplify fractions.
Determine factors and multiples for specified whole numbers.
Relate halves, fourths, tenths, and hundredths to decimals and percents.
Estimate and describe reasonableness of estimates; determine the appropriateness of an estimate versus an exact answer.
Identify and relate prime and composite numbers, factors and multiples within the context of fractions.
Use the order of operations to simplify expressions which include exponents and parentheses.
Describe real-world situations using positive and negative numbers.
Compare, order, and graph integers, including integers shown on a number line.
Solve non-routine problems using various strategies including "solving a simpler problem" and "guess, check, and revise."
Use equivalent forms of fractions, decimals, and percents to solve problems.
Compare and order fractions, decimals, and percents, including finding their approximate location on a number line.
Estimate the results of computations with fractions, decimals, and percents and judge the reasonableness of the results.
Express rational numbers as terminating or repeating decimals.
Solve non-routine problems by working backwards.
Use exponents and scientific notation to write large and small numbers and vice versa and to solve problems.

Make reasonable approximations of square roots and mathematical expressions that include square roots, and use them to estimate solutions to problems and to compare mathematical expressions involving real numbers and radical expressions.
Simplify real number expressions using the laws of exponents.

Perform operations on real numbers (including integer exponents, radicals, percents, scientific notation, absolute value, rational numbers, and irrational numbers) using multi-step and real world problems.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Solve real-world problems involving addition facts with sums to 10 and related subtraction facts using numerals with sets of objects and pictures.
Solve real-world problems involving simple joining (putting together) and separating (taking apart) situations with sets of objects to 5.
Demonstrate distinctive responses to preferred vs. non-preferred stimuli in two familiar routines.
Solve problems involving addition of the same number such as 1+1 or 2+2 with sums to 10.
Solve problems involving combining sets with the same number of objects with sums to 4 using one-to-one correspondence and counting.
Communicate the desire for one preferred item or activity in familiar routines.
Express, represent, and use cardinal numbers 0 to 30 and ordinal numbers to tenth using sets of objects or pictures, number names, and numerals.
Compare and order whole numbers 0 to 30 using objects, pictures, or tallies, and a number line..
Apply the concepts of counting and grouping to create sets of tens and ones to identify the value of whole numbers to 30.
Use skip counting by 5s to determine amounts to 30.
Express and represent numbers to 10 using sets of objects and pictures, number names, and numerals.
Use one-to-one correspondence to count sets of objects to 10.
Compare and order numbers to 10 using sets of objects and pictures.
Communicate the desire for two or more preferred items or activities in familiar routines.
Match two or more objects to designated spaces to show one-to-one correspondence.
Respond to a prompt to indicate one object in familiar routines.
Given a model, imitate counting two or more objects or actions.
Express, represent, and use whole numbers 0 to 50 in various contexts, including money.
Compare and order whole numbers to 50 using pictures or tallies and a number line.
Use the inverse relationship of addition and subtraction as a strategy to solve problems.
Use skip counting by 5s and 10s to determine amounts to 50.
Use strategies such as comparing and grouping to estimate quantities to 10.
Express, represent, and use whole numbers to 18 using sets of objects and pictures, number names, and numerals in various contexts, including money.
Count, compare, and order numbers 0 to 18 using sets of objects and pictures with numerals.
Use objects and pictures to represent the relationship between addition and subtraction facts.
Use ordinal numbers, including first and second, in real-world situations.
Respond to a prompt to identify a specified part of an object.
Solve problems by selecting a preferred or necessary item from two or more options in a routine.
Use skip counting to identify multiples of 2, 5, and 10 for numbers to 100.
Identify place value of twodigit numbers to 99 in terms of tens and ones.
Express, represent, and use whole numbers to 100 in various contexts, including time, money, and measurement.
Solve real-world addition and subtraction problems with one-digit numbers by estimating and checking for accuracy.
Solve for an unknown number in addition and subtraction number sentences with numbers to 18.
Demonstrate basic calculator skills for addition and subtraction of whole numbers.
Select the operation and solve one-step problems involving addition or subtraction of two-digit numbers without regrouping and check for accuracy.
Use skip counting by 5s to 30.
Apply the concepts of counting and grouping to identify the value of whole numbers to 30.
Express, represent, and use cardinal numbers to 30 and ordinal numbers to fifth in various contexts, including time and money.
Compare and order whole numbers to 30 using objects, pictures, number names, and numerals.
Solve real-world problems involving addition facts with sums to 18 and related subtraction facts using numerals with pictures.
Indicate 1 and 1 more by imitating a model.
Match an object, picture, or symbol to an identical object, picture, or symbol in routines using one-to-one correspondence.
Imitate counting objects or actions to 3 or more given a model.
Respond to a prompt to exchange a predetermined amount of money for a preferred object.
Solve problems by selecting preferred or necessary item from options in two or more routines.
Compare fractional parts of the same size objects or sets, including halves, fourths, thirds, and eighths.
Identify the value of money to $1.00 expressed as a decimal Examples: $.75 is 75 cents. $.60 is 60 cents.
Express, represent, and use whole numbers to 200 in various contexts, including time, money, and measurement.
Use a grouping strategy or place value to round to the nearest ten to determine a reasonable estimate in problem situations involving whole numbers to 100, and check for accuracy.
Solve problems involving the addition and subtraction of two-digit whole numbers with regrouping using physical and visual models.
Solve two-step real-world problems involving addition and subtraction of two-digit numbers and check for accuracy using the reverse operation.
Express, represent, and use whole numbers to 50 using objects, pictures, number names, and numerals, in various contexts including time and money.
Compare and order whole numbers to 50 using objects, pictures, number names, and numerals.
Apply the concepts of counting and grouping to identify the value of whole numbers to 50.
Use basic calculator skills to enter basic addition and subtraction facts with one-digit numbers to obtain the solution to problems.
Match two or more objects to identical objects in routines using one-to-one correspondence.
Imitate counting objects or actions to 2 or more in multiple activities.
Respond to a gesture or imitate a model to exchange a predetermined amount of money for a preferred item.
Solve problems by selecting preferred or necessary item given two or more options in different routines in multiple settings.
Express, represent, and use whole numbers to 500 in various contexts, including time, money, and measurement.
Express, represent, and use fractions, including halves, fourths, thirds, and eighths, using whole objects or sets, number names, and numerals in various contexts, including measurement.
Express, represent, and use percents, including 50% and 100%, and decimals in the context of money to $1.00 or more.
Use a grouping strategy or place value to round whole numbers to 500 to the nearest ten or hundred to determine a reasonable estimate in problem situations, and check for accuracy.
Express, represent, and use cardinal numbers to 80 and ordinal numbers to tenth in various contexts, including time and money.
Express and represent fractions, including halves and fourths, using whole objects or sets, number names, and numerals.
Identify the value of individual coins written as a decimal.
Apply the concepts of counting and grouping to create sets of tens and ones to identify the value of whole numbers to 80.
Communicate desire for more, none, and less in activities in the school setting.
Identify a specified part of two or more objects.
Count objects or actions to 3 or more.
Respond to a gesture or imitate a model to exchange a predetermined amount of money for a preferred object.
Solve problems by selecting the preferred or necessary item when given two or more options in activities in multiple settings.
Express, represent, and use whole numbers to 1000 in various contexts, including time, money, and measurement.
Express, represent, and use fractions including halves, fourths, thirds, eighths, and sixths using whole objects or sets, number names, and numerals in various contexts, including measurement.
Express, represent, and use percents, including 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100%; and decimals in the context of money.
Use a grouping strategy or place value to round whole numbers to 1000 to the nearest ten or hundred to determine a reasonable estimate in problem situations, and check for accuracy.
Express, represent, and use whole numbers to 100 in various contexts, including time and money.
Express, represent, and use fractions, such as halves, fourths, and thirds, using whole objects or sets, pictures, number names, and numerals in various contexts.
Use counting, grouping, and place value to identify the value of whole numbers to 100.
Identify values of individual coins and bills written as a decimal.
Identify percents including 50% and 100%.
Identify a specified part of three or more objects.
Count objects or actions to 3 or more in multiple activities.
Identify quantity/number in sets to 3.
Respond to a gesture or imitate a model to exchange a predetermined amount of money for a preferred object in the school setting.
Communicate desire for more, none, and less in two or more activities in the school setting.
Solve problems by selecting the preferred or necessary item when given three or more options for different activities in multiple settings.
Data Analysis
Construct and analyze frequency tables, bar graphs, pictographs, and line plots from data, including data collected through observations, surveys, and experiments.
Construct and analyze line graphs and double bar graphs.
Differentiate between continuous and discrete data and determine ways to represent those using graphs and diagrams.
Determine the measures of central tendency (mean, median, and mode) and variability (range) for a given set of data.
Select and analyze the measures of central tendency or variability to represent, describe, analyze and/or summarize a data set for the purposes of answering questions appropriately.
Evaluate the reasonableness of a sample to determine the appropriateness of generalizations made about the population.
Construct and analyze histograms, stem-and-leaf plots, and circle graphs.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Sort and count objects and pictures into three designated (labeled) categories and display data in an object graph or pictograph.
Sort objects representing data into two designated (labeled) categories and count the number in each category.
Identify items that belong together to complete a data set.
Indicate preferred choice using objects, pictures, or symbols to create an object graph or pictograph.
Sort and count data into three designated (labeled) categories, and display data on a pictograph or bar graph.
Interpret the meaning of data in a three-category pictograph or bar graph.
Sort and count objects or pictures into two designated (labeled) categories and display data in an object graph or pictograph.
Identify the meaning of data in a two-category object graph or pictograph.
Imitate counting up to three familiar objects, pictures, or symbols in data sets.
Use a bar graph to group and display data in categories.
Identify the categories with the largest and smallest numbers represented on a bar graph.
Sort and count data using three designated (labeled) categories and display in a pictograph.
Identify the category with the largest number in a pictograph representing real-world situations.
Identify familiar objects, pictures, or symbols used to represent data in a pictograph or chart.
Identify the largest set of objects, pictures, or symbols representing data up to 3.
Use bar graphs to display data and describe the meaning of the data.
Use data from a part of a group (sample) to make predictions regarding the whole group.
Use pictographs to display data in designated (labeled) categories and identify the number in each category.
Compare data shown in a pictograph with three categories and describe which categories have the largest, smallest, or the same amount.
Count the objects, pictures, or symbols used in a pictograph or chart and identify total to 3 or more.
Probability
Determine the outcome of an experiment and predict which events are likely or unlikely, and if the experiment is fair or unfair.
Determine, compare, and make predictions based on experimental or theoretical probability of independent or dependent events.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Predict the likely outcome of a simple experiment and conduct the experiment to determine if prediction was correct.
Predict the likely outcome of a simple experiment by selecting from two choices and check to see if the prediction was correct.
Solve problems by selecting preferred or necessary item given two or more options in different activities in multiple settings.

text: Algebra Body Of Knowledge

children.text: Standard 1: Real and Complex Number Systems
Know equivalent forms of real numbers (including integer exponents and radicals, percents, scientific notation, absolute value, rational numbers, irrational numbers).
Compare real number expressions.
Simplify real number expressions using the laws of exponents.

Perform operations on real numbers (including integer exponents, radicals, percents, scientific notation, absolute value, rational numbers, and irrational numbers) using multi-step and real-world problems.
Use dimensional (unit) analysis to perform conversions between units of measure, including rates.
Identify the real and imaginary parts of complex numbers and perform basic operations.
Represent complex numbers geometrically.
Use the zero product property of real numbers in a variety of contexts to identify solutions to equations.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities

Identify and use equivalent forms of fractions, such as halves, fourths, thirds, sixths, eighths, tenths, and sixteenths; decimals to the hundredths place; and percents, such as 25%, 50%, 75%, 100%, 33%, and 67%, using visual and numerical representation in real-world situations.
Identify examples of positive and negative whole numbers in real-world situations.
Determine the value of numbers to 10 with the exponents 2 and 3, such as 4² and 3³, using physical and visual patterns.
Compare and order numbers, including whole numbers, fractions, decimals, and percents, expressed in the same form to solve problems in real-world situations.
Simplify fractions and decimals by reducing to lowest terms.
Simplify improper fractions, such as 8/4, by using division facts.

Select the operation and solve two-step mathematical problems involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division of two- and three-digit numbers in real-world situations using problem-solving strategies, such as recognizing symbols and key information and using visual representations.
Use tools, including charts and technology, to convert standard units of measurement within the same system, such as money, length, capacity, time, and weight.

Identify equivalent forms of fractions, such as halves, thirds, and fourths; percents, such as 50%, 33%, and 25%; and decimals in the context of money using visual and numerical representation in real-world situations.
Identify the value of numbers to 5 with the exponent 2 using physical and visual models.
Compare and order whole numbers, fractions, including halves, fourths, thirds, and sixths; and decimals including .25, .50, .75, 1.00, in real-world situations, including money and measurement.
Simplify whole numbers to 100 using place value and grouping with visual representation.

Select the operation and solve one-step mathematical problems involving addition and subtraction of one-digit and two-digit numbers in real-world situations using physical and visual representations and problem-solving strategies, such as recognizing key information and symbols.
Use tools, such as simple charts and technology, to convert standard units of measurement within the same system, such as money, length, and capacity.
Communicate desire for more, none, and less in activities in real-world activities.
Identify a missing part of an object, picture, or symbol.
Count objects or actions to 5 or more in multiple activities.
Standard 2: Relations and Functions
Create a graph to represent a real-world situation.
Interpret a graph representing a real-world situation.
Describe the concept of a function, use function notation, determine whether a given relation is a function, and link equations to functions.
Determine the domain and range of a relation.
Graph absolute value equations and inequalities in two variables.
Identify and graph common functions (including but not limited to linear, rational, quadratic, cubic, radical, absolute value).
Perform operations (addition, subtraction, division and multiplication) of functions algebraically, numerically, and graphically.
Determine the composition of functions.
Recognize, interpret, and graph functions defined piece-wise, with and without technology.
Describe and graph transformations of functions
Solve problems involving functions and their inverses.
Solve problems using direct, inverse, and joint variations.
Solve real-world problems involving relations and functions.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Create simple bar, line, and circle graphs to represent data from real-world situations.
Interpret simple bar, line, and circle graphs representing data from real-world situations.
Identify the mathematical relationship (function) and the type of information represented in a function table or simple graph.
Use function tables and simple graphs to determine the mathematical relationship between two numbers representing real-world situations.
Organize data from real-world situations into categories, identify the labels, and display in pictographs and bar graphs.
Identify which categories have the largest, smallest, or the same amount in pictographs and bar graphs representing realworld situations.
Identify number patterns and relationships using physical and visual models representing real-world situations.
Match objects, pictures, or symbols based on a model using one-to-one correspondence to complete tasks in real-world activities.
Identify a quantity to 4 or higher and add 1 more in routines or activities.
Identify a quantity to 5 and take 1 away in routines or activities.
Count the objects, pictures, or symbols used in a pictograph or chart and identify total to 5 or more.
Standard 3: Linear Equations and Inequalities
Solve linear equations in one variable that include simplifying algebraic expressions.
Identify and apply the distributive, associative, and commutative properties of real numbers and the properties of equality.
Solve literal equations for a specified variable.
Solve and graph simple and compound inequalities in one variable and be able to justify each step in a solution.
Symbolically represent and solve multi-step and real-world applications that involve linear equations and inequalities.
Solve and graph the solutions of absolute value equations and inequalities with one variable.
Rewrite equations of a line into slope-intercept form and standard form.

Graph a line given any of the following information: a table of values, the x- and y-intercepts, two points, the slope and a point, the equation of the line in slope-intercept form, standard form, or point-slope form.
Determine the slope, x-intercept, and y-intercept of a line given its graph, its equation, or two points on the line.

Write an equation of a line given any of the following information: two points on the line, its slope and one point on the line, or its graph. Also, find an equation of a new line parallel to a given line, or perpendicular to a given line, through a given point on the new line.

Write an equation of a line that models a data set and use the equation or the graph to make predictions. Describe the slope of the line in terms of the data, recognizing that the slope is the rate of change.
Graph a linear equation or inequality in two variables with and without graphing technology. Write an equation or inequality represented by a given graph.
Use a graph to approximate the solution of a system of linear equations or inequalities in two variables with and without technology.
Solve systems of linear equations and inequalities in two and three variables using graphical, substitution, and elimination methods.
Solve real-world problems involving systems of linear equations and inequalities in two and three variables.
Access Points for Students with Significant Cognitive Disabilities
Solve equations with one unknown (variable) involving addition, multiplication, subtraction, and division of whole numbers representing problems in real-world situations.
Use the commutative, associative, and equality properties of addition as strategies to solve equations involving real-world situations.
Use the commutative and associative property of multiplication and the properties of one and zero for multiplication as strategies to solve equations involving real-world situations.
Solve real-world equations and inequalities with one unknown (variable) using visual models to represent the procedure.
Create function tables and simple graphs that show the mathematical relationship between number pairs.
Use function tables and simple graphs representing equations to make predictions for real-world situations.
Solve number sentences (equations) involving addition and subtraction of one-digit and two-digit whole numbers based on real-world situations using visual models.
Use the commutative property and the additive identity property of addition as a strategy to solve number sentences (equations).
Use the concepts of equality and inequality as strategies to solve problems involving real-world situations.
Solve equations involving addition and subtraction using visual models, such as a number line, in real-world situations.
Use repeated addition of the same number to solve one-digit multiplication facts and repeated subtraction of the same number to solve one-digit division facts in real-world situations.
Use function tables and simple graphs representing equations to make predictions for real-world situations.
Match two sets of objects, pictures, or symbols to identical items in real-world tasks using one-to-one correspondence.
Identify quantities to 4 or more and add 1 more in real-world tasks.
Identify quantities to 5 or more and take 1 away in real-world tasks.
Standard 4: Polynomials
Simplify monomials and monomial expressions using the laws of integral exponents.
Add, subtract, and multiply polynomials.
Factor polynomial expressions.
Divide polynomials by monomials and polynomials with various techniques, including synthetic division.
Graph polynomial functions with and without technology and describe end behavior.
